resources.string: Pied-billed Grebe

(Podilymbus podiceps) is a species of the grebe family of water birds. Since the Atitlán grebe (Podilymbus gigas) has become extinct, it is the sole extant member of the genus Podilymbus. The pied-billed grebe is primarily found in ponds throughout the Americas. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pied-billed_grebe
Horned Grebe

(Podiceps auritus) is a relatively small waterbird in the family Podicipedidae. There are two known subspecies: P. a. auritus, which breeds in the Palearctic, and P. a. cornutus, which breeds in North America. The Eurasian subspecies is distributed over most of northern Europe and the Palearctic, breeding from Greenland to western China. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horned_grebe
Double-crested Cormorant

(Phalacrocorax auritus) is a member of the cormorant family of seabirds. Its habitat is near rivers and lakes as well as in coastal areas, and is widely distributed across North America, from the Aleutian Islands in Alaska down to Florida and Mexico. Measuring 70–90 cm (28–35 in) in length, it is an all-black bird which gains a small double crest of black and white feathers in breeding season. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-crested_cormorant
American Bittern

(Botaurus lentiginosus) is a species of wading bird in the heron family. It has a Nearctic distribution, breeding in Canada and the northern and central parts of the United States, and wintering in the U.S. Gulf Coast states. It is a well-camouflaged, solitary brown bird that unobtrusively inhabits marshes and the coarse vegetation at the edge of lakes and ponds. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_bittern
Least Bittern

(Ixobrychus exilis) is a small heron, the smallest member of the family Ardeidae found in the Americas. The least bittern is one of the smallest herons in the world, with perhaps only the dwarf bittern and the black-backed bittern averaging smaller in length. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_bittern
Great blue heron

(Ardea herodias) is a large wading bird in the heron family Ardeidae, common near the shores of open water and in wetlands over most of North America and Central America , as well as the Caribbean and the Galápagos Islands. It is a rare vagrant to coastal Spain, the Azores, and areas of far southern Europe. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_blue_heron
Great egret

(Ardea alba), also known as the common egret, large egret, great white egret or great white heron is a large, widely distributed egret, with four subspecies found in Asia, Africa, the Americas, and southern Europe. Distributed across most of the tropical and warmer temperate regions of the world, it builds tree nests in colonies close to water. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_egret
Snowy Egret

(Egretta thula) is a small white heron. The genus name comes from the Provençal French for the little egret aigrette, a diminutive of aigron, "heron". The species name thula is the Araucano for the black-necked swan, applied to this species in error by Chilean naturalist Juan Ignacio Molina in 1782. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowy_egret
Green heron

(Butorides virescens) is a small heron of North and Central America. Butorides is from Middle English butor "bittern" and Ancient Greek -oides, "resembling", and virescens is Latin for "greenish". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_heron
Trumpeter swan

(Cygnus buccinator) is a species of swan found in North America. The heaviest living bird native to North America, it is also the largest extant species of waterfowl with a wingspan that may exceed 10 ft (3.0 m). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumpeter_swan
Tundra swan

(Cygnus columbianus) is a small Holarctic swan. The two taxa within it are usually regarded as conspecific, but are also sometimes split into two species: Bewick\'s swan (Cygnus bewickii) of the Palaearctic and the whistling swan (C. columbianus) proper of the Nearctic. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tundra_swan
Greater white-fronted goose

(Anser albifrons) is a species of goose related to the smaller lesser white-fronted goose (A. erythropus). It is named for the patch of white feathers bordering the base of its bill, in fact albifrons comes from the Latin albus "white" and frons" forehead ". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_white-fronted_goose
Canada goose

(Branta canadensis) is a large wild goose species with a black head and neck, white cheeks, white under its chin, and a brown body. Native to arctic and temperate regions of North America, its migration occasionally reaches northern Europe. It has been introduced to the United Kingdom , Ireland, New Zealand, Argentina, Chile, and the Falkland Islands. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada_goose
Wood duck
(Aix sponsa) is a species of perching duck found in North America. It is one of the most colorful North American waterfowl. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wood_duck
Mallard

(Anas platyrhynchos) is a dabbling duck that breeds throughout the temperate and subtropical Americas, Eurosiberia, and North Africa and has been introduced to New Zealand, Australia , Peru, Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile, Colombia, the Falkland Islands, and South Africa. This duck belongs to the subfamily Anatinae of the waterfowl family Anatidae. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mallard
American black duck

(Anas rubripes) is a large dabbling duck in the family Anatidae. It was described by William Brewster in 1902. It is the heaviest species in the genus Anas, weighing 720–1,640 g (1.59–3.62 lb) on average and measuring 54–59 cm (21–23 in) in length with a 88–95 cm (35–37 in) wingspan. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_black_duck
Gadwall

(Mareca strepera) is a common and widespread dabbling duck in the family Anatidae. The gadwall is 46–56 cm (18–22 in) long with a 78–90 cm (31–35 in) wingspan. The male is slightly larger than the female, weighing on average 990 g (35 oz) against her 850 g (30 oz). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gadwall
Northern shoveler

(Spatula clypeata) is known simply in Britain as the shoveler, is a common and widespread duck. It breeds in northern areas of Europe and across the Palearctic and across most of North America, wintering in southern Europe, Africa, the Indian subcontinent, Southeast Asia, and Central, and northern South America. It is a rare vagrant to Australia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_shoveler
Blue-winged teal

(Spatula discors) is a species of bird in the duck, goose, and swan family Anatidae. One of the smaller members of the dabbling duckgroup, it occurs in North America, where it breeds from southern Alaska to Nova Scotia, and south to northern Texas. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue-winged_teal
Green-winged teal

(Anas carolinensis or Anas crecca carolinensis) is a common and widespread duck that breeds in the northern areas of North America except on the Aleutian Islands. It is highly gregarious outside of the breeding season and will form large flocks. In flight, the fast, twisting flocks resemble waders. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green-winged_teal
American wigeon

(Mareca americana) is also called a baldpate, is a species of dabbling duck found in North America. Formerly assigned to Anas, this species is classified with the other wigeons in the dabbling duck genus Mareca.The American wigeon is a medium-sized bird; it is larger than a teal, but smaller than a pintail. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_wigeon
Northern pintail

(Anas acuta) is a duck with wide geographic distribution that breeds in the northern areas of Europe and across the Palearctic and North America. It is migratory and winters s outh of its breeding range to the equator. This is a large duck, and the male\'s long central tail feathers give rise to the species\' English and scientific names. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_pintail
Canvasback

(Aythya valisineria) is a species of diving duck, the largest found in North America. It is the largest species in the genus Aythya, being similar in size to a mallard but with a heavier and more compact build than it. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canvasback
Redhead

(Aythya americana) is a medium-sized diving duck is 37 cm (15 in) long with an 84 cm (33 in) wingspan. It belongs to the genus Aythya, together with 11 other described species. The redhead and the common pochard form a sister group which together is sister to the canvasback. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redhead_(bird)
Ring-necked duck

(Aythya collaris) is a diving duck from North America commonly found in freshwater ponds and lakes. Ring-necked ducks are small to medium-sized diving ducks. The adult male is similar in color pattern to the Eurasian tufted duck, its relative. Males are a little bit bigger than the female. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring-necked_duck
Lesser scaup

(Aythya affinis) is a small North American diving duck that migrates south as far as Central America in winter. It is colloquially known as the little bluebill or broadbill because of its distinctive blue bill. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesser_scaup
Bufflehead

(Bucephala albeola) is a small sea duck of the genus Bucephala, the goldeneyes. The bufflehead ranges from 32–40 cm (13–16 in) long and weighs 270–550 g (9.5–19.4 oz), with the drakes larger than the females. It rivals the green-winged teal as the smallest American duck. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bufflehead
Hooded merganser

(Lophodytes cucullatus) is a species of small diving duck. It is the only extant species in the genus Lophodytes. The bird is striking in appearance; both sexes have crests that they can raise or lower, and the breeding plumage of the male is handsomely patterned and coloured. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hooded_merganser
Ruddy duck
(Oxyura jamaicensis) is a duck from North America and one of the stiff-tailed ducks. The hooded merganser is a sexually dimorphic species. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruddy_duck
Turkey vulture

(Cathartes aura) is also known in some North American regions as the turkey buzzard. The turkey vulture is a scavenger and feeds almost exclusively on carrion. It finds its food using its keen eyes and sense of smell, flying low enough to detect the gasses produced by the beginnings of the process of decay in dead animals. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey_vulture
Osprey

(Pandion haliaetus) is a diurnal, fish-eating bird of prey with a cosmopolitan range. It is a large raptor, reaching more than 60 cm (24 in) in length and 180 cm (71 in) across the wings. It is brown on the upperparts and predominantly greyish on the head and underparts. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osprey
Sharp-shinned hawk

(Accipiter striatus) is a small hawk, with males being the smallest hawks in the United States and Canada, but with the species averaging larger than some Neotropical species, such as the tiny hawk. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharp-shinned_hawk
Cooper’s hawk

(Accipiter cooperii) is also known as the Cooper hawk, is a medium-sized hawk native to the North American continent and found from Southern Canada to Northern Mexico. This species is a member of the genus Accipiter, sometimes referred to as true hawks, which are famously agile, relatively small hawks common to wooded habitats around the world and also the most diverse of all diurnal raptor genera. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooper%27s_hawk
Red-shouldered hawk

(Buteo lineatus) is a medium-sized hawk. Its breeding range spans eastern North America and along the coast of Californiaand northern to northeastern-central Mexico. Red-shouldered hawks are permanent residents throughout most of their range, though northern birds do migrate, mostly to central Mexico. The main conservation threat to the widespread species is deforestation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-shouldered_hawk
Red-tailed hawk

(Buteo jamaicensis) is a bird of prey that breeds throughout most of North America, from the interior of Alaska and northern Canada to as far south as Panama and the West Indies. It is one of the most common members within the genus of Buteo in North America or worldwide. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-tailed_hawk
Rough-legged hawk

(Buteo lagopus), also called the rough-legged hawk, is a medium-large bird of prey. It is found in Arctic and Subarctic regions of North America and the Palearctic during the breeding season and migrates south for the winter. It was traditionally also known as the rough-legged falcon in such works as John James Audubon\'s The Birds of America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough-legged_buzzard
Bald eagle

(Haliaeetus leucocephalus) is a bird of prey found in North America. A sea eagle, it has two known subspecies and forms a species pairwith the white-tailed eagle (Haliaeetus albicilla). Its range includes most of Canada and Alaska, all of the contiguous United States, and northern Mexico. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle
American kestrel

(Falco sparverius) is the smallest and most common falcon in North America. It has a roughly two-to-one range in size over subspecies and sex, varying in size from about the weight of a blue jay to a mourning dove. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_kestrel
Peregrine falcon

(Falco peregrinus), also known as the peregrine, and historically as the duck hawk in North America, is a widespread bird of prey (raptor) in the family Falconidae. A large, crow-sized falcon, it has a blue-grey back, barred white underparts, and a black head. The peregrine is renowned for its speed, reaching over 320 km/h (200 mph) during its characteristic hunting stoop (high-speed dive). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peregrine_falcon
Wild turkey

(Meleagris gallopavo) is an upland ground bird native to North America, one of two extant species of turkey, and the heaviest member of the diverse Galliformes. It is the same species as the domestic turkey, which was originally derived from a southern Mexican subspecies of wild turkey (not the related ocellated turkey). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wild_turkey
King rail

(Rallus elegans) is a waterbird, the largest North American rail. Distinct features are a long bill with a slight downward curve, with adults being brown on the back and rusty-brown on the face and breast with a dark brown cap. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_rail
Virginia rail

(Rallus limicola) is a small waterbird, of the family Rallidae. These birds remain fairly common despite continuing loss of habitat, but are secretive by nature and more often heard than seen. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_rail
Sora

(Porzana carolina) is a small waterbird of the family Rallidae, sometimes also referred to as the sora rail or sora crake. The genus name Porzanais derived from Venetian terms for small rails, and Carolina refers to the Carolina Colony. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sora_(bird)
American coot

(Fulica americana), also known as a mud hen or pouldeau, is a bird of the family Rallidae. Though commonly mistaken for ducks, American coots are only distantly related to ducks, belonging to a separate order. Unlike the webbed feet of ducks, coots have broad, lobed scales on their lower legs and toes that fold back with each step in order to facilitate walking on dry land. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_coot
Sandhill crane

(Antigone canadensis) is a species of large crane of North America and extreme northeastern Siberia. The common name of this bird refers to habitat like that at the Platte River, on the edge of Nebraska\'s Sandhills on the American Plains. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandhill_crane
Killdeer

(Charadrius vociferus) is a large plover found in the Americas. It was described and given its current scientific name in 1758 by Carl Linnaeusin the 10th edition of his Systema Naturae. There are three subspecies. The killdeer\'s common name comes from its often-heard call. Its upperparts are mostly brown with rufous fringes, the head has patches of white and black, and there are two black breast bands. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Killdeer
Greater yellowlegs

(Tringa melanoleuca) is a large North American shorebird. The genus name Tringa is the New Latin name given to the green sandpiper by Aldrovandus in 1599 based on Ancient Greek trungas, a thrush-sized, white-rumped, tail-bobbing wading bird mentioned by Aristotle. The specific melanoleuca is from Ancient Greek melas, "black", and leukos, "white". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_yellowlegs
Lesser yellowlegs

(Tringa flavipes) is a medium-sized shorebird. The genus name Tringa is the New Latin name given to the green sandpiper by Aldrovandus in 1599 based on Ancient Greek trungas, a thrush-sized, white-rumped, tail-bobbing wading bird mentioned by Aristotle. The specific flavipesis from Latin flavus, "yellow", and pes, "foot". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesser_yellowlegs
Solitary sandpiper

(Tringa solitaria) is a small shorebird. This species measures 18–23 cm (7.1–9.1 in) long, with a wingspan up to 50 cm (20 in) and a body mass of 31–65 g (1.1–2.3 oz). It is a dumpy waderwith a dark green back, greyish head and breast and otherwise white underparts. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solitary_sandpiper
Spotted sandpiper

(Actitis macularius) is a small shorebird. Adults have short yellowish legs and an orange bill with a dark tip. The body is brown on top and white underneath with black spots. Non-breeding birds do not have the spotted underparts, and are very similar to the common sandpiper of Eurasia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spotted_sandpiper
Dunlin

(Calidris alpina) is a small wader. An adult dunlin in breeding plumage shows the distinctive black belly which no other similar-sized wader possesses. The winter dunlin is basically grey above and white below. Juveniles are brown above with two whitish "V" shapes on the back. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunlin
Least sandpiper

(Calidris minutilla) is the smallest known shorebird. They tend to breed in North America on tundra or in bogs. They nest on the ground near water. The female lays four eggs in a shallow scrape lined with grass and moss. Both parents have been observed to incubate their eggs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least_sandpiper
Pectoral sandpiper

(Calidris melanotos) is a small, migratory wader. Pectoral sandpipers make their nest by scraping a whole in the ground and with a thick lining, is deep enough to protect its four eggs from the cool breezes of its breeding grounds. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pectoral_sandpiper
Wilson’s snipe

(Gallinago delicata) is a small, stocky shorebird. The name of this bird is meant to commemorate the American ornithologist Alexander Wilson. They breed in marshes, bogs, tundra and wet meadows in Canada and the northern United States and on the Chukchi Peninsula, Russia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilson%27s_snipe
American woodcock

(Scolopax minor) is a small chunky shorebird species found primarily in the eastern half of North America. Woodcocks spend most of their time on the ground, partly due to the fact that their plumage Provides extremely good camouflage. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_woodcock
Ring-billed gull

(Larus delawarensis) is a medium-sized gull. The ring-billed gulls\' breeding habitat is near lakes, rivers, or the coast in Canada and the northern United States. They nest colonially on the ground, often on islands. This bird tends to be faithful to its nesting site, if not its mate, from year to year. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring-billed_gull
Herring gull

(Larus smithsonianus or Larus argentatus smithsonianus) is a large gull that breeds in North America. Adults are white with gray back and wings, black wingtips with white spots, and pink legs. Immature birds are gray-brown and are darker and more uniform than European herring gulls, with a darker tail. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_herring_gull
Rock dove

(Columba livia) is a member of the dove family, Columbidae. In common use, it is Usually just referred to as a “pigeon”. Coloration varies between wild and domestic rock Doves. These birds are extremely common and widespread across most of the world. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_dove
Mourning dove

(Zenaida macroura) is a member of the dove family, Columbidae. It’s also referred to as the turtle dove. It is one of the most abundant and widespread of all North American birds. It is a gamebird, as more than 20 million are killed annually for sport or for meat. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mourning_dove
Black-billed cuckoo

(Coccyzus erythropthalmus) is a New World species in the Cuculidae (cuckoo) family. The scientific name is from Ancient Greek. The genus name kokkuzo, means to call like a common cuckoo, and erythropthalmus is from eruthros, "red" and ophthalmos, "eye". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-billed_cuckoo
Yellow-billed cuckoo

(Coccyzus americanus) is a species of cuckoo. They are also referred to as a Storm crow, likely because they are known to sing on hot days, often before rain or thunder. Their range spans from North America to South America, and can sometimes be seen in western Europe. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow-billed_cuckoo
Barred owl

(Strix varia) is a large species of owl. These owls are native to eastern North America, but have expanded their range all the way to the west coast, where they are considered an invasive species. Their diet consists mostly of small mammals, but will prey upon almost any living creature that is small enough. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_owl
Common nighthawk

(Chordeiles minor) is a medium sized bird in the nightjar family. These birds are Nocturnal. However, their hunting process ends when dusk becomes night, and resumes again as night becomes dawn. They will rarely feed in complete darkness. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_nighthawk
Chimney swift

(Chaetura pelagica) is a bird that belongs to the swift family Apodidae. The Chimney Swift is named after its soot-grey color, and has been placed in the vulnerable category, meaning it is currently a threatened species. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chimney_swift
Ruby-throated hummingbird

(Archilochus colubris) is a hummingbird that spends its time in eastern North America during the summer to breed. The rest of the year, it is a resident of Central America, Mexico, and parts of Florida. It is the most common hummingbird on the east of the Mississippi. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruby-throated_hummingbird
Belted kingfisher

(Megaceryle alcyon) is a large, conspicuous water kingfisher. This bird is the only member of its group that can be found in North America. Adult males are white and blue, while females are white and grey. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belted_kingfisher
Red-headed woodpecker

(Melanerpes erythrocephalus) is a small to medium sized woodpecker. It is native to temperate North America. Up until 2018, this bird was considered to be near threatened, but has recently moved back to the category of least concern, after habitat management stabilized their numbers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-headed_woodpecker
Red-bellied woodpecker

(Melanerpes carolinus) is a medium sized woodpecker. It belongs to the family Picidae. Although its name would indicate that it has a red belly, it does not. Instead, the Red-bellied woodpecker is white and black with a red marking covering most of the head. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-bellied_woodpecker
Downy woodpecker

(Dryobates pubescens) is the smallest species of woodpecker in North America. They like to nest in dead trees or limbs, which are excavated by the nesting pair. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downy_woodpecker
Hairy woodpecker

(Leuconotopicus villosus) is a medium sized woodpecker. They are colored mostly black and white, and adults tend to have red patches on their head. They are permanent residents and only migrate in extreme situations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hairy_woodpecker
Northern flicker

(Colaptes auratus) is a medium sized bird in the woodpecker family. It is native to parts of North America, Central America, Cuba, and the Cayman Islands. It is one of the only woodpeckers that have been observed to migrate. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_flicker
Pileated woodpecker

(Dryocopus pileatus) is a woodpecker that is native to North America. It is the second largest woodpecker on the continent. It gets the name “pileated” from its prominent, red-crested head, which comes from the word pileatus meaning "capped" in Latin. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pileated_woodpecker
Olive-sided flycatcher

(Contopus cooperi) is a medium sized passerine bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. This bird has a very peculiar flight pattern, where it likes to fall sharply after climbing in altitude. These birds are labeled as near threatened, likely due to loss of habitat. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olive-sided_flycatcher
Eastern wood-pewee

(Contopus virens) is a small bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. It is native to North America. However, it will migrate to Central America and the Andes region of South America during winter. Their diet consists mainly of insects caught mid-flight. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_wood_pewee
Yellow-bellied flycatcher

(Empidonax flaviventris) is a small bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. They like to breed in wet northern woods, particularly in spruce bogs. Their nests are typically formed in sphagnum moss near or at ground level. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow-bellied_flycatcher
Acadian flycatcher

(Empidonax virescens) is a small bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. They like to breed in deciduous forests near water. During winter, these birds will migrate to eastern Mexico, the Caribbean, and northwest South America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acadian_flycatcher
Willow flycatcher

(Empidonax traillii) is a small, neotropical bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. They are migratory birds, and span from the west coast to the east coast of the United States, avoiding only the southeast corner of the country. There are four subspecies, three of which only breed in California. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willow_flycatcher
Eastern phoebe

(Sayornis phoebe) is a small passerine bird. These bird are migratory, and can be observed in the eastern portions of Central America, the U.S., and central areas of Canada. Some Eastern phoebes have been seen in western Europe, but not very often. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_phoebe
Great crested flycatcher

(Myiarchus crinitus) is a large bird of the tyrant flycatcher family. These birds are typically found in the treetops, and are rarely ever seen on the ground. Their song is called the dawn song, because they typically sing at this time, searching for a mate. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_crested_flycatcher
Eastern kingbird

(Tyrannus tyrannus) is a large tyrant flycatcher. It is native to North America. Some Eastern kingbirds have been observed leaving their nests out in the open, while others have a tendency to thoroughly hide their nest location. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_kingbird
White-eyed vireo

(Vireo griseus) is a small songbird. These birds are known to eat insects, including caterpillars, during breeding months. At other points in the year, they can be seen eating berries instead. They tend to reside in eastern regions of the U.S., but will spend time farther south in places like eastern Mexico and Central America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-eyed_vireo
Yellow-throated vireo

(Vireo flavifrons) is a small American songbird. They are migratory, traveling as far south as the northernmost region of South America, and spending other parts of the year in the eastern region of The U.S. Some of these birds have been observed in western Europe, but this is very rare. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow-throated_vireo
Warbling vireo

(Vireo gilvus) is a small songbird. It’s song is noted to be cheerful, with slight differences between western and eastern residing vireos. Some officials consider these two, the western and eastern vireos, as two seperate species. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warbling_vireo
Red-eyed vireo

(Vireo olivaceus) is a small American songbird. It bears a strong resemblance to a warbler, but is not closely related however. They are colored olive-green and white, and are named after their Distinctive red iris. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-eyed_vireo
Blue jay

(Cyanocitta cristata) is a large passerine bird of the family Corvidae. It is native to North America, and resides mainly in the central and eastern portions of the United States. It will breed in both deciduous and coniferous forests, and has been commonly observed in residential areas. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_jay
American crow

(Corvus brachyrhynchos) is a large passerine bird of the family Corvidae. American crows are very common and extremely widespread. Due to their susceptibility to the West Nile virus, they have been a useful bioindicator for humans to track the spread of the virus. Contrary to some beliefs, transmission of the virus directly from crow to human is impossible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_crow
Barn swallow

(Hirundo rustica) is the most widespread species of swallow known to man, and is also a passerine bird. It is known for its blue coloration, and forked tail. There are six subspecies of the Barn swallow, four of which are recorded as being strongly migratory. These birds are closely associated with humans, which humans benefit from as well, due to their insect eating habits. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barn_swallow
Tree swallow

(Tachycineta bicolor) is a bird in the family Hirundinidae. They are vibrant blue in color, and females will typically be a little bit duller than males. The Tree swallow is a migratory bird, and will span From Alaska, all the way to Mexico in the span of its life. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_swallow
Purple martin

(Progne subis) is the largest swallow in North America. Despite their name, they are not actually purple. However, they have an iridescent sheen that can cause them to appear in many different colors. They are known for their speed and agility, and are regarded as very good flyers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purple_martin
Northern rough-winged swallow

(Stelgidopteryx serripennis) is a small swallow. It is a migratory bird that is native to the U.S. and central america. These birds like to nest in the burrows of soil banks, but sometimes in caves or trees, and other times in human made formations like gutters and tubes.
Bank swallow

(Riparia riparia) is a passerine bird in the swallow family. They are migratory, and have an extremely wide range of habitats that span across most of the world. These birds usually nest directly Into the ground, preferring a very specific kind of ground (known as loess) to burrow in. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sand_martin
Cliff swallow

(Petrochelidon pyrrhonota) is a passerine bird in the family Hirundinidae. These birds are extremely social, and can be found nesting in colonies of 2,000 nests or more. They like to build their nests close together, using vocalizations to warn others of danger and to communicate food availability. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_cliff_swallow
Carolina chickadee

(Poecile carolinensis) is a small passerine that belongs in the tit family Paridae. During fall and winter migration, these birds tend to flock together, including many other kinds of species in the flocks, such as titmice, nuthatches, and warblers. Other birds love chickadees because they call out when they find good sources of food. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolina_chickadee
Black-capped chickadee

(Poecile atricapillus) is a small songbird. It is a passerine that belongs in the tit family Paridae. These birds have a tendency to live in deciduous and mixed forests, spending their time on tree branches foraging for food. They are also known to be non-migratory. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-capped_chickadee
Brown creeper

(Certhia americana) is a small songbird, and happens to be the only North American bird that belongs in the treecreeper family Certhiidae. They tend to breed in Coniferous forests in portions of Alaska and Canada, as well as the western and northeastern regions of the U.S.. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_creeper
Tufted titmouse

(Baeolophus bicolor) is a small songbird that is a part of the tit and chickadee Family. This bird is known to have a song that resembles a whistle, and can vary in 20 different observed ways. The Tufted titmouse is non-migratory, and native to Ohio as well as Mississippi. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tufted_titmouse
White-breasted nuthatch

(Sitta carolinensis) is a small songbird that belongs in the nuthatch family. These birds are commonly seen in temperate portions of the United States. During winter months, they tend to feed on seeds. But during other times of the year, will forage for insects on branches and trunks. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-breasted_nuthatch
Sedge wren

(Cistothorus stellaris) is a small passerine bird that belongs in the family Troglodytidae. These birds are often found in tall wetlands and meadows, because they like to nest in tall grasses to feed on insects. Sedge wrens have been observed to improvise their songs rather than learn to sing from other birds. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedge_wren
Marsh wren

(Cistothorus palustris) is a small songbird that belongs in the wren family. It is sometimes called the long-billed marsh wren to distinguish it from the shorter billed sedge wren. These birds will typically forage near bodies of water, and will sometimes catch insects out of the air. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marsh_wren
Carolina wren

(Thryothorus ludovicianus) Is a common species of wren that is located in the eastern half of the United States, including some of south Canada and north Mexico as well. They prefer to live in dense forests and suburban areas. This form of wren is the state bird of South Carolina. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolina_wren
House wren

(Troglodytes aedon) is an extremely small songbird, and a part of the wren family. They are the most widely distributed bird in the Americas. Their diet consists of butterfly larvae, spiders, snails, and other similar insects. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_wren
Golden-crowned kinglet

(Regulus satrapa) is an extremely small songbird. It is in the family Regulidae, and lives in most of Northern America. Golden-crowned kinglets have been noted for their lack of fear for humans. They like to forage in trees and shrubs, where they eats insects, insect eggs, and spiders. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden-crowned_kinglet
Blue-gray gnatcatcher

(Polioptila caerulea) is an extremely small songbird. While both sexes of these birds have differing color patterns, males and females both have a distinctive white ring that goes around each eye. They forage in trees and shrubs, eating things like insects, insect eggs, or even spiders. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue-gray_gnatcatcher
Eastern bluebird

(Sialia sialis) is a small thrush. These birds tend to live in open woodlands farmlands, or orchards. They are very social, oftentimes flying in flocks of one-hundred or more. Their diet consists of insects, fruits, and berries. However, they favor grasshoppers, crickets, katydids, and beetles among other prey. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_bluebird
Veery

(Catharus fuscescens) is a small member of the North American thrush species. During breeding season, they mainly eat insects. However, during summer and fall, their diet changes. At which point, they prefer fruits and berries. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veery
Wood thrush

(Hylocichla mustelina) is a North American passerine bird. The song sung by male Wood thrushes is highly regarded as the most beautiful in North America. Also, they tend to be territorial, and will defend large areas around its nest. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wood_thrush
American robin

(Turdus migratorius) is a migratory Songbird. Its named after its similarly colored counterpart, the European robin, although the two are not closely related. They have been known to breed very early in the year, and are typically the earliest bird to sing at dawn. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_robin
Gray catbird

(Dumetella carolinensis) is a member of the family Mimidae. Its a North American and Central American perching bird, which was named for its cat-like song. They have been observed to interact with humans the most during winter months. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_catbird
Northern mockingbird

(Mimus polyglottos) is the only mockingbird that can be commonly found in North America. These birds like to stay put, but will migrate south if weather becomes too harsh during winter months. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_mockingbird
Brown thrasher

(Toxostoma rufum) is a member of the family Mimidae. It is the only thrasher that is known to live primarily east of central Texas. They are known to sing over 1000 song, which is the largest song repertoire of any kind of bird. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_thrasher
Cedar waxwing

(Bombycilla cedrorum) is a member of the family Bombycillidae. Cedar waxwings are known to be sociable and non-territorial, and can be seen grooming each other from time to time. Their flocks typically move place to place to find good sources of berries. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cedar_waxwing
European starling

(Sturnus vulgaris) is a medium sized passerine bird of the starling family. Its known for its ability to mimic the songs of other bids. These birds are seen as beneficial for agriculture, because they control pest populations. In certain situations, however, they can be seen as a past themselves since they sometimes feed on fruit and crops. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_starling
Yellow warbler

(Setophaga petechia) is a New World wabler. This bird is known for being extremely widespread, since it breeds in all of North America and some of northern South America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_yellow_warbler
Yellow-rumped warbler

(Setophaga coronata) is a combination of several different types of warblers. These birds are known to like coniferous and mixed coniferous-deciduous woodlands during breeding season. At other points in the year, they tend to stay in places like streamside woodlands, pine forests, or residential areas. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow-rumped_warbler
Palm warbler

(Setophaga palmarum) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family. This bird has two distinct subspecies that differ in color. One of these subspecies, known as the yellow palm warbler, is mostly yellow with some brown markings. On the other hand, its counterpart, the brown palm warbler, is mostly brown with some yellow markings. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palm_warbler
American redstart

(Setophaga ruticilla) is a New World warbler. These birds feed almost entirely on insects, which they either flycatch or glean from leaves. This species also has a skewed sex ratio that results in a large number of unmated males. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_redstart
Prothonotary warbler

(Protonotaria citrea) is a small songbird of the New World warbler family. It is the only member of the genus Protonotaria. It is the only known eastern warbler that likes to nest in natural cavities, such as a woodpecker hole. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prothonotary_warbler
Common yellowthroat

(Geothlypis trichas) is a New World warbler. These birds like to breed in marshes, or other areas that are wet with dense low vegetation. Male yellowthroats have a black mask-like marking that covers their face. Females have been observed to choose males with the largest mask. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_yellowthroat
Yellow-breasted chat

(Icteria virens) is a large songbird, native to North America. It is the only known member of the Icteriidae family. It used to be a member of the New World warbler family until 2017, when the American Ornithological Society decided it should be in its own. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow-breasted_chat
Scarlet tanager

(Piranga olivacea) is a medium sized American songbird. It is classified as a part of both the cardinal family, and the tanager family. It bears many similarities to cardinals, but lacks the conical bill that cardinals need for seed and insect eating. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarlet_tanager
Rose-breasted grosbeak

(Pheucticus ludovicianus) is a large bird in the cardinal family that feeds mostly on seeds. These birds tend to live longer in captivity, since they often die in the wild by collision with things like buildings or cars. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose-breasted_grosbeak
Indigo bunting

(Passerina cyanea) is a small bird in the cardinal family. It feeds mostly on seeds, and uses the stars to navigate when migrating. It has been observed interbreeding with the closely related Lazuli bunting bird when they cross paths. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigo_bunting
Northern cardinal

(Cardinalis cardinalis) is a bird of the Cardinalis genus. They are the same as a common cardinal or cardinal. It has a distinctive crest on the head and a mask on the face. Males are very vibrantly red, and females have a faded red color. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_cardinal
Eastern towhee

(Pipilo erythrophthalmus) is a large bird that was formerly accepted as the same species as the Spotted Towhee. Before being identified as separate birds, they were both known as the rufous-sided towhee. the name "towhee" was derived from their very distinctive song. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_towhee
American tree sparrow

(Spizelloides arborea) is also known as a Winter sparrow. It is a medium sized bird that prefers colder climates. It breeds in the northern limits of Alaska and Canada, but will migrate south to the bottom of Canada and all of the U.S. for winter. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_tree_sparrow
Chipping sparrow

(Spizella passerina) is a type of American sparrow. It is widely spread across Northern America and mostly tame. It molts twice a year, meaning that it takes on different color patterns depending on if it is breeding season or not. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chipping_sparrow
Field sparrow

(Spizella pusilla) is a small bird in the family of Passerellidae. It can be seen in eastern portions of the United States and Canada. The habitat of this bird tends to be shrubs and grasslands. They tend to build nests on the ground, feeding mostly on seeds and insects. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_sparrow
Song sparrow

(Melospiza melodia) is an extremely common, variable, and adaptive species from North America. They tend to have brown bodies with white underbellies, covered in black streaking. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_sparrow
Swamp sparrow

(Melospiza georgiana) is medium sized and closely related to the (more well known) Song sparrow. They typically breed in marshes, where they build nests close to water level. Their diet consists mainly of fruit, seeds, and arthropods. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swamp_sparrow
White-throated sparrow

(Zonotrichia albicollis) is a species of passerine. They have been observed to have two distinct variations of coloring known as the tan striped, and the white striped forms. They tend to breed in Canada and New England but migrate to Mexico and eastern America in the winter. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-throated_sparrow
White-crowned sparrow

(Zonotrichia leucophrys) is a species of passerine. It is native to North America and can be observed in almost all parts of it. These birds are typically grey with black and white striping on the head. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-crowned_sparrow
Dark-eyed junco

(Junco hyemalis) is seen in temperate North America, but will venture as far as the Arctic in Summer months. These birds are known to have varying physical features. However, they are typically grey with white bellies. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark-eyed_junco
Orchard oriole

(Icterus spurius) is the smallest known icterid. It has been known to breed from northeast America to eastern Mexico, and will spend winters as far south as South America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orchard_oriole
Baltimore oriole

(Icterus galbula) is a small icterid blackbird which is common to eastern regions of North America. The Baltimore oriole is know to interbreed with the western Bullocks oriole, leading to both being classified as a single species; the Northern Oriole. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_oriole
Red-winged blackbird

(Agelaius phoeniceus) is a passerine bird, or perching bird, which can be distinguished by the arrangement of their toes (3 forward 1 back). It has been argued to be one of the most abundant living land birds in North America. Due to the abundance of this bird, it tops the list as one of the most studied wild birds in the wild. Male and female red-winged blackbirds are colored completely different. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-winged_blackbird
Eastern meadowlark

(Sturnella magna) is a medium sized bird. It is seen primarily in the eastern portions of North and South America. It is very similar in appearance to the western meadowlark, and is often mistaken as such. The difference in song from the western to eastern meadowlark is typically the easiest way to differentiate between the two. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_meadowlark
Common grackle

(Quiscalus quiscula) is a large bird that can be found all around much of north America. It is commonly seen in large numbers. Groups of common Grackles are referred to as a "plague". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_grackle
Brown-headed cowbird

(Molothrus ater) is a small bird that is native to subtropical North America. It is brood parasitic, meaning it relies on others to help raise their young. In winter, it may migrate south as far as Mexico. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown-headed_cowbird
House sparrow

(Passer domesticus) is a part of the sparrow family. This bird is common to most parts of the world. Being that its been introduced to such a high number of regions around the globe, it is regarded as being THE most widely distributed wild bird. It can be found in a wide variety of habitats and climates, including urban environments. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_sparrow
American goldfinch

(Spinus tristis) is a part of the finch family. It is known to be a migrative bird. During the winter, it can be found anywhere from the US-Canada border to Mexico. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_goldfinch
House finch

(Haemorhous mexicanus) is a part of the finch family. It is originally native to western North America, but has since been introduced in the east as well as Hawaii. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_finch
